title: GE CARESCAPE Canvas – Will Not Power On
description: Basic power troubleshooting for a GE CARESCAPE Canvas patient monitor.

steps.title: Make Sure the Monitor Has Power
instructions: Confirm the monitor is plugged into an outlet that you know is working.
If unsure, plug in another device (lamp, phone charger, etc.) to test the outlet.
If the monitor is plugged into a power strip or isolation transformer, make sure that device is also turned on.

steps.title: Check the Power Cord
instructions: Look over the power cord for cuts, fraying, bent or broken prongs.
Make sure the cord is pushed in firmly at the wall outlet and back of the monitor.

CCR.Cause: Monitor shows no power with known-working outlet and known-good power cord. No indicator lights or screen activity observed. Suspected internal power failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed from service and sent for repair.

helpfulDetails: Final status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: Philips V60 Ventilator – Fails Self-Test / Flow Sensor Error
description: Basic troubleshooting for a Philips V60 ventilator reporting a flow sensor error or failing self-test.

steps.title: Inspect the Patient Circuit
instructions: Make sure all tubing connections are secure and fully seated.
Check for cracks, holes, or loose fittings.
Confirm there are no kinks or obstructions that could block flow.
Even a small leak or disconnection can trigger a flow sensor error.

steps.title: Check the Flow Sensor Module
instructions: Locate the flow sensor in the circuit (usually near the patient connection or ventilator port).
Make sure it is properly installed and seated.
Inspect for visible damage, moisture, or condensation.
A loose or wet sensor can prevent the ventilator from reading flow accurately.

steps.title: Verify Humidifier or Additional Circuit Components
instructions: If a humidifier is in use, ensure it is seated correctly and tubing is fully connected.
Check for any other inline devices (filters, adapters) that may affect flow readings.
Any extra resistance or leaks in these components can trigger a flow sensor alarm.

steps.title: Observe the Ventilator Display
instructions: Note the error code and any additional messages.
Record what you see for documentation purposes.
Philips V60 often displays a specific flow sensor error with a code — writing it down helps CE staff track recurring issues.

steps.title: Try a Simple Reset
instructions: Power off the ventilator.
Reseat the circuit and flow sensor connections.
Power back on and rerun the self-test.
If the error clears, the ventilator may be returned to service. If not, escalate.

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator fails self-test; flow sensor error.
CCR.Cause: Circuit and flow sensor inspected and reseated, humidifier checked, no visible damage. Error persists. Suspected internal flow sensor or electronic issue.
CCR.Resolution: Removed ventilator from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair or tagged for bench evaluation by CE.

helpfulDetails: Any visible damage, moisture, or condensation
Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: Welch Allyn Connex 6000 Series – NIBP Failure
description: Basic troubleshooting for a Welch Allyn Connex 6000 monitor reporting NIBP failure due to leaky hose or transducer drift.

steps.title: Inspect the NIBP Hose
instructions: Ensure the hose connecting the cuff to the monitor is fully seated at both ends.
Look for cracks, holes, kinks, or wear along the hose.
Replace the hose if any visible damage or leaks are observed.
Even a small leak can prevent proper inflation and trigger an NIBP error.

steps.title: Check the Cuff and Connections
instructions: Confirm the cuff is the correct size for the patient.
Make sure the cuff tubing is fully inserted and the hook/Velcro is secure.
Inspect for tears or leaks in the bladder.
A poorly seated or damaged cuff can cause failed or inaccurate readings.

steps.title: Verify the Module / Transducer Seating
instructions: Make sure the NIBP module is fully inserted in the monitor.
Check the connector pins for cleanliness and damage.
Look for visible moisture or debris.
Loose or misaligned transducers can cause drift or persistent errors.

steps.title: Observe the Display
instructions: Note any error codes (e.g., “NIBP Fail,” “Low Pressure,” “Leak Detected”).
Record whether the error happens immediately or intermittently.
Documenting details helps CE staff identify recurring issues.

steps.title: Try a Simple Reset
instructions: Remove the cuff and hose from the patient.
Power cycle the monitor.
Reconnect the hose and cuff, and attempt another measurement.
If the measurement succeeds, the issue may have been a temporary connection or seating problem.

CCR.Cause: Hose inspected and intact, cuff verified, module seated correctly. Measurement still fails. Suspected transducer drift or internal module fault.
CCR.Resolution: Removed monitor from service, labeled Out of Service, sent for repair or tagged for bench evaluation by CE.

helpfulDetails: Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: Philips V60 Ventilator – Fails Self-Test / Leak Detected
description: Basic troubleshooting when a Philips V60 ventilator fails its self-test due to a leak detected.

steps.title: Check the Patient Circuit and Tubing
instructions: Make sure the breathing circuit is fully connected at all connection points.
Confirm there are no loose fittings, cracks, or obvious holes in the tubing.
Ensure the circuit is properly seated on the ventilator outlet.
Even a small gap or loose connection can cause a leak failure during self-test.

steps.title: Inspect the Exhalation Port and Filter
instructions: Verify the exhalation port is installed correctly.
Check that the filter is present and seated properly.
Look for moisture buildup or blockage that could affect airflow.
Improper installation or obstruction can cause the ventilator to detect a leak.

steps.title: Check the Humidifier (If Installed)
instructions: Confirm the humidifier chamber is seated correctly.
Make sure the chamber is not cracked or leaking.
Verify all humidifier tubing connections are tight.
Leaks in the humidifier setup are a common cause of failed leak tests.

steps.title: Inspect the Mask or Test Plug
instructions: If a mask is attached, make sure it is sealed properly.
If running a self-test without a patient, ensure the test plug or circuit is capped correctly.
An open or poorly sealed patient interface will cause the self-test to fail.

steps.title: Try a Simple Reset
instructions: Power the ventilator off.
Re-seat the circuit, exhalation port, and humidifier connections.
Power the ventilator back on and rerun the self-test.
If the self-test passes, the ventilator may be returned to service.

CCR.Cause: Patient circuit, exhalation port, and humidifier inspected and reseated. No visible damage noted. Self-test continues to fail with leak detected. Suspected internal leak or valve failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed ventilator from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair or tagged for bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ZOLL R Series – Printer Not Printing / Paper Jam (Thermal Paper)
description: Troubleshooting for ZOLL R Series defibrillator when the printer will not print or reports a paper jam using thermal paper.

steps.title: Check the Paper Stack
instructions: Ensure there is a paper stack loaded in the printer’s tray.
Confirm the leading edge of the top sheet is correctly positioned in the feed mechanism.
Replace the stack if it is empty, wrinkled, or damaged.
Note: Thermal paper is sensitive to heat, pressure, and folds. Crumpled or old paper may not feed properly or print.

steps.title: Inspect for Paper Jams
instructions: Open the printer cover and remove any misfed or stuck sheets.
Look for small bits of torn paper or debris blocking the feed path.
Ensure the feed path is clear before closing the cover.
Thermal paper jams can occur if the stack is compressed too tightly or the edges are bent.

steps.title: Verify Printer Cover is Closed Properly
instructions: The printer will not operate if the cover is not fully closed.
Close the printer cover until it clicks into place.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good Thermal Paper Stack (If Available)
instructions: If the printer still fails to print, replace the current stack with a new, known-good thermal paper stack.
Attempt a test print or generate a report from the device.

steps.title: Observe the Device Display
instructions: Note exactly what the display or status indicator shows: “Paper Jam”, “Printer Error”, or “Insert Paper”.
Record the message for documentation and trend tracking.

CCR.Complaint: Printer will not print / paper jam.
CCR.Cause: Paper stack loaded and properly seated, but printer still displays jam error. Paper cleared and cover closed. Suspected printer mechanism or thermal feed issue.
CCR.Resolution: Replaced thermal paper stack and cleared feed path; printer now functional.

helpfulDetails: Paper stack loaded correctly and in good condition: yes / no
Final status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ZOLL R Series – Pads Not Detected / Therapy Cable Failure
description: Troubleshooting for ZOLL R Series defibrillator when pads are not detected, often due to a therapy cable failure.

steps.title: Check That the Pads Are Connected Properly
instructions: Ensure both therapy pads are securely attached to the therapy cable.
Confirm the pads are fully inserted into the connector port on the defibrillator.
Loose connections can prevent the device from recognizing the pads.

steps.title: Inspect the Pads and Cable for Damage
instructions: Look for cracked or torn pads, exposed wires, frayed or twisted cable.
Replace pads or cable if any visible damage is present.
Even small damage can cause the device to detect a failure.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good Pad Set or Cable (If Available)
instructions: Remove the current pads or therapy cable and connect a known-good set.
Observe if the defibrillator recognizes them correctly.
This helps determine whether the issue is with the cable, pads, or device itself.

steps.title: Observe the Device Display
instructions: Note exactly what the display or status indicator shows: “Pads Not Detected” or “Therapy Cable Failure”.
Pay attention to whether the message appears immediately or intermittently.
Even small details help identify intermittent cable or connector issues.

steps.title: Check Pad Expiration
instructions: Verify that the pads are within their expiration date.
Expired pads may not properly connect or be recognized by the device.

CCR.Complaint: Defibrillator reports pads not detected / therapy cable failure.
CCR.Cause: Pads and cable inspected, no visible damage. Tested with known-good pads/cable: issue resolved. Suspected faulty therapy cable.
CCR.Resolution: Removed faulty cable/pads from service and replaced with known-good set.

helpfulDetails: Pads/cable inspected for damage: yes / no
Final status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ZOLL R Series – Battery Fails Self-Test
description: Basic battery troubleshooting for a ZOLL R Series defibrillator reporting a failed self-test.

steps.title: Make Sure the Battery Is Fully Seated
instructions: Confirm the battery is installed correctly in the defibrillator.
Remove the battery and reinsert it, making sure it clicks or seats firmly into place.
A loose battery can cause self-test failures even if the battery itself is good.

steps.title: Check the Battery Contacts
instructions: Inspect the battery and device contacts for dirt or debris.
Look for corrosion or bent or damaged pins.
If safe to do so, gently clean visible debris from the contacts and reinsert the battery.
Poor contact between the battery and device can cause charging and self-test issues.

steps.title: Verify the Battery Has Been Charging
instructions: Confirm the defibrillator has been plugged into AC power when stored.
Check for any charging or status indicators that show the battery has been receiving power.
A battery that has not been charging may fail self-test due to low capacity.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good Battery (If Available)
instructions: Remove the current battery and insert a known-good battery from another unit.
Allow the unit to complete its self-test again.
This helps determine whether the issue is with the battery or the defibrillator itself.

steps.title: Observe the Self-Test Message or Indicator
instructions: Note exactly what the display or status indicator shows.
Does it say "Battery Fail"?
Does it say "Replace Battery"?
Does it fail immediately or after charging?
Even small details can help determine the cause.

CCR.Cause: Battery fails self-test after reseating and charging. Alternate battery passes self-test. Suspected failed battery pack.
CCR.Resolution: Removed battery from service and replaced with known-good battery.

helpfulDetails: Final status (battery replaced or sent for repair)

title: GE B850 Monitor – Power Issue / Will Not Turn On
description: Basic power troubleshooting for a GE B850 patient monitor.

steps.title: Make Sure the Monitor Has Power
instructions: Confirm the monitor is plugged into an outlet that you know is working.
If unsure, plug in another device (lamp, phone charger, etc.) to test the outlet.
If the monitor is plugged into a power strip or isolation transformer, make sure that device is also turned on.

steps.title: Check the Power Cord
instructions: Look over the power cord for cuts, fraying, or bent/broken prongs.
Make sure the cord is pushed in firmly at both the wall outlet and the back of the monitor.
Loose connections can make the monitor appear dead even when power is available.

steps.title: Confirm the Power Switch Is On
instructions: Locate the power switch on the monitor.
Make sure it is set to the ON position.
Try pressing the front power button again.

steps.title: Watch for Any Signs of Life
instructions: When attempting to power on, observe the monitor closely.
Do any lights turn on? Does the screen flash briefly? Do you hear a fan or clicking sound?
Even small signs can help determine what is happening internally.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good Power Cord (If Available)
instructions: Swap it with the current one.
Try powering the monitor on again.
A faulty cord can look perfectly normal from the outside.

CCR.Cause: Monitor shows no power with known-working outlet and known-good power cord. No indicator lights or screen activity observed. Suspected internal power failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed from service and sent for repair or tagged out of service for further bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Final status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: Baxter SIGMA Spectrum Infusion Pump – Occlusion Alarm / Will Not Start Infusion
description: Basic troubleshooting when a SIGMA Spectrum infusion pump shows an occlusion alarm and will not start infusion.

steps.title: Check the IV Set and Tubing
instructions: Make sure the tubing is properly loaded into the pump.
Confirm there are no kinks, twists, or sharp bends in the line.
Check that clamps are fully open and not blocking fluid flow.
Even a small pinch or bend can trigger an occlusion alarm.

steps.title: Inspect the Pump Door and Cassette
instructions: Ensure the cassette or disposable set is seated correctly.
Close the door fully — the pump may not start if it senses the door is ajar.
Some alarms are triggered if the cassette isn’t aligned properly.

steps.title: Check the Fluid Bag or Syringe
instructions: Make sure there is fluid in the bag or syringe.
Confirm that the tubing is primed — air in the line can sometimes trigger an occlusion alarm.

steps.title: Observe the Pump Display and Alarm
instructions: Look for any other messages on the display.
Note the type of alarm shown (for example: occlusion, warning, or low fluid).
Record what you see — this helps when documenting.

steps.title: Try a Simple Reset
instructions: Stop the pump.
Remove and reload the tubing.
Close the door and restart the pump.
If the alarm clears, the pump may resume infusion.

CCR.Complaint: Pump will not start infusion; occlusion alarm displayed.
CCR.Cause: Tubing and cassette inspected, tubing free of kinks, door fully closed, fluid present. Alarm persists. Suspected internal pump sensor issue.
CCR.Resolution: Removed pump from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair or tagged for bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Any unusual sounds or display behavior
Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)
